key_title: Key to the species of Viola

Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Violaceae

source.author: Entwisle, T.J.
source.title: Viola
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Entwisle, T.J. (1996). Viola. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Annual or biennial; stipules to 4 cm long, green, deeply lobed; lower petal broad-cuneate
Perennials; stipules small, often brownish, translucent; lower petal ovate to linear-oblong
Plants not stoloniferous (but usually rhizomatous), stems often elongated and decumbent; lower petal spurred; flowers without scent
Plants stoloniferous (rarely also rhizomatous), stems rarely elongated; lower petal shallowly pouched or spurred; flowers with or without scent
Stems lax, elongated; leaves scattered along stem or at nodes, lamina ovate to circular, base cordate
Stems erect, short; leaves in basal rosette, lamina lanceolate, obovate or oblong, base truncate, cuneate or slightly cordate
Stipules entire or sparsely toothed; corolla white or rarely pale violet; native, usually riparian species of eastern Victoria
Stipules fimbriate; corolla blue-violet; uncommon garden-escape
Leaf base cuneate to shallowly cordate, lamina more or less ovate; petiole + lamina mostly less than 15 cm long
Leaf base hastate, lamina triangular, margins straight or concave; petiole + lamina usually more than 15 cm long
Petiole with short deflexed hairs, flowers usually strongly scented; lower petal spurred; capsule hairy
Petiole glabrous, or if hairy, the hairs not deflexed; flowers without scent or faintly scented; lower petal shallowly pouched but not spurred; capsule usually glabrous

Flowers usually 1 colour, sometimes indistinctly 2-coloured; petals 2–7 mm long; leaves usually with lamina ovate, rhombic or spathulate, as long as wide or longer, withbase cuneate and tapering to petiole (but leaves wider than long and semi-circular to reniform in rare V. curtisiae from the Baw Baws)
Flowers rather distinctly 2-coloured, petals 7–10 mm long; leaves with lamina reniform to more or less circular, often broader than long, base mostly truncate or cordate, sometimes cuneate
Flower-scapes 3–8 cm long, usually exceeding the leaves; flowers pale to mid blue-violet; western, from Grampians area to SA border
Flower-scapes less than 3 cm long, usually shorter than or only just exceeding the leaves; flowers blackish-violet, pale blue-violet or cream
Petals 5–7 mm long, pale blue-violet or white
Petals less than 4 mm long, blackish-violet or cream
Leaves rhombic to ovate, wider than long; Nunniong Plateau
Leaves semi-circular to reniform, longer than wide; Baw Baws

Corolla cream, often with a purplish tinge towards the centre; lower petal c. 1 mm wide, linear to oblong; leaves generally longer than wide; mostly dryish lowland forests and sandy heaths of southern Victoria
Corolla blackish-violet, lower petal c. 2 mm wide, obovate to elliptic; leaves generally wider than long; mainly damp, peaty ground of alps but with isolated occurrences in south Gippsland
Anterior petal broadest in the distal third, venation somewhat irregular; petals with indistinct demarcation between violet and white areas; seeds dull, cream to brown, usually mottled
Anterior petal broadest in the proximal third or at the mid-point, venation regularly triplinerved; petals with sharp demarcation between violet and white areas; seeds glossy, purple-black
Flowers blackish-violet, with or without small white tips to the petals
Flowers bright violet and white, with prominent white (rarely pale violet) tips to the petals
Anterior petal broadest in the proximal third; leaves reniform, wider than long, with a broad sinus or truncate at base; mostly moist to wet forests, typically montane to subalpine
Anterior petal broadest at the mid-point; leaves reniform to orbicular, about as long as wide, often with a deep, narrow sinus; escapees from horticulture
